paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere, as inferred from JWST MIRI thermal phase-curve spectroscopy and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band, and what does the dataset imply about day-night heat transport and plausible atmospheric composition?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: JWST MIRI LRS phase-curve spectroscopy
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One orbital phase curve of TRAPPIST-1 b
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Low-resolution JWST MIRI spectroscopy taken over an orbital phase curve, providing phase-resolved thermal spectra used to measure thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock (no-atmosphere) null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Model scenario used as a comparator
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A no-atmosphere, bare-rock model with minimal heat redistribution used as the baseline comparator against which phase amplitude and spectral band behavior are evaluated.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere retrieval family
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Model retrieval family fit to the phase curve + spectrum
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere-bearing retrieval models that include significant greenhouse-gas absorption (including the 15 um CO2 band) to jointly constrain heat transport and atmospheric pressure/composition.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere retrieval family
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized (O2-rich) atmosphere scenarios explored as an alternative to CO2-rich cases, with current data providing weaker constraints on CO2 spectral signatures and not fully ruling these cases out.

major_limitations: Single-planet study; does not establish prevalence across M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, clouds) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.
